subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, we’ll be exploring the subject of
listening to animals. With me is Miranda
Alcott. She has a Master’s Degree in
Spiritual Psychology and has been
working in the area of inter-species
communication for decades. Miranda is an
old friend and I believe the first time
I interviewed her was about 20 years ago.
Welcome Miranda. Thank you, Jeffery. Thank
you so much for asking us. And, this is Rumi…
Want to sit up? Rumi is your
teammate… Rumi is my teammate and he is
my service dog.
I’m not sure he’s going to sit up right
now. Yeah.
Well, what a pleasure to be with you
again, Miranda. Thank you for inviting me.
This is very exciting. I just want to
say at the beginning, thank you for how
much you do for all of us.
Your education and what you share and
making it available to everyone is
definitely up-leveling everything that
happens on this planet, so thank you. Well,
I’m happy to make my little contribution.
I think you’re making an important
contribution as well. I think it’s worth
saying that in addition to your work as
an animal communicator, which also
involves opening up
people, opening up humans to various
levels of intuitive communication, you do
emergency work. I do. I do crisis
response and have done that for
many years.
So, thank you for your service.
It's small, but I love it. Now,
a lot of people don’t
realize that animals are available for
communication. In fact,
certainly in the fields of
psychology, physiology, animal science,
there’s been an attitude for a long time
that they don’t have feelings, they don’t
have thoughts and the worst thing that a
human can do is
anthropomorphize their animals with
whom they interact. Right. And that’s
interesting as science is actually
starting to catch up just a little bit
with that, studying the different breeds
of dogs, the ones that are smarter, asking
them for a larger vocabulary of
what they understand. Wondering why it is
that we now have PTSD dogs
for active duty soldiers, returning,
and why they’re so successful.
Why are these dogs that are working with
these soldiers that come home
with so many challenges, why are they
successful? How come the dogs are able to
save the humans’ lives when as humans we
aren’t able to do that yet?
So, very important. That’s a huge
cutting edge area I’m very excited about. In
other words, what you’re saying is,
not only can we learn to listen to what
animals are trying to communicate to us,
but they’re trying to teach us, as
well, we can learn from them. Absolutely.
They have the most incredible
ability to focus and center us when we
are in crisis.
If they deem there’s a problem, they’re
on high alert.
But, those animals that are working with
people that have different disabilities,
myself being one of them, they are tuned into
what we need, innately. Because they look
at it as a matter of survival and
they’re bonding with us. So, they become
our ears, they become our eyes,
very well trained. And
that’s why I’m very supportive of the
PTSD dogs.
Now, when you say a PTSD dog, you’re
referring to a dog who is also
experiencing
something akin to what humans with PTSD,
post-traumatic stress disorder,
experience. Well, there are dogs that have...
animals that have post-traumatic stress disorder. It has to do with the
amygdala and if the amygdala is involved
in a traumatic experience it's going
to hardwire
what it is that it needs to protect us
from.
But, I was referring to the dogs that
work with soldiers returning from active
duty who come home
with PTSD
and it’s very hard for them to focus and
center. Many times, they just keep
reliving, like we think of a video loop,
of what they’ve been through…
The person… The person… and the animals have this
incredible, innate ability to calm and
bring that person back in focus,
back into their bodies to ground. OK. An
incredibly valuable service. Now,
this must require special skill on the
part of the animal because the humans
that you are referring to are not
necessarily skilled at listening. That’s
right. That’s true. They’re skilled in
being aware of everything that is around
them, which means that their adrenals
have been on high alert all through
their service.
So, a lot of times they have
deficits in their awareness,
but they are feeling that they are completely aware.
They can be exposed to sounds that
trigger them, the humans,
and the animals have a way of getting
their attention, whether it's jumping up,
whether it's laying on them, whether it's
lying across their bodies when they have
night time night terrors, and bringing
them back into focus. In other words, the
animal functions as a therapist.
Absolutely. The animal steps in and is
able to calm that person down.
And if people are able to better listen
to animals, that process could be
facilitated further. Right. Exactly. And,
you know, in the students that I
have, the biggest
challenge that most of them have
is that as a culture we were raised not
to listen to animals. That growing
up as children we may have had imaginary friends, and that was sort of put in the
category of, of course your animal is not
talking to you, of course it's not.
We’re finding out that’s very different
now. We’re finding out… most people
actually inside want to believe that
they can hear their animals, but it’s
been trained out of them as they grew up
in our society, but there are entire cultures that do...
Are you saying that when a child, who has
a pet, also has an imaginary friend,
the imaginary friend
may actually be the animal
communicating? Exactly, that may be it.
Yeah, it's very exciting. And, many
times when I get the wonderful
opportunity to work with children, usually seven and under, somewhere in
there, they will openly tell you what
their animals are saying. It depends on what happens at home. As a matter
of fact, one of the things I really love
is working with someone who is pregnant,
their baby is in utero and the animal
and the baby are communicating.
It is fascinating and sometimes it's
absolutely hilarious because the dog
cannot imagine that a human would be
born and not know they don't have teeth.
Because that is part of what a dog is
born with. You have to come in with teeth. You must come in with teeth, that's
protection, that's who you are. So,
some of the funny conversations that I
watched it go on, is the dog will say to
the baby whose spirit is ready to be
born into a physical
existence: “I have your back.”
The child, as many of them are very
old souls returning, will say, “What do you
mean you have my back? Why do I need that?”
“Well, because you don't have any teeth.”
This child is not you know….
The parents absolutely love it. They
absolutely love it. So, it depends on if
the family is supportive to let the
child express what's going on,
it becomes very rewarding. So,
also what I'm hearing here is that just
as humans have a tendency to
anthropomorphize
an animal, a dog might have a tendency
to think of us as if we were canine. Yes,
only we have certain problems.
We’re pretty slow, by their standards.
We don't have fur, which is a real
problem because it's protection. So,
many times when we see animals licking
babies they're just trying to
stimulate the growth of fur.
So, we have lots of drawbacks from that
canid culture.
Isn't that interesting.
Well, what intrigues me is the
modalities through which the
communication occurs. You, for example, I
understand, you get a lot of visual
imagery when you communicate with animals.
Lots of pictures, we think of it maybe as
in videos.
Part of my job is to express to
whoever I'm working with, how that fits
into what we’re asking, what the questions are.
Many times the animals have so much to
share about us. I mean, they really do know more about us than we know about
them. Lots of times when there's an animal
that has a behavioral issue,
it's acting out what's going on in the
family. When the family decides they
need help then I start introducing: if
you could just watch this behavior you
might see a reflection,
and then listening to your animal.
Listening takes practice and a lot of
work, it does,
but most people
are remembering at some point that they
actually can hear the telepathy, that
they do hear the telepathic messaging.
It's natural for us.
We all use telepathy. Part of our
listening is to use telepathy. Even in a
conversation like this. Even in a conversation like this.
So, even if we're talking about
someone whose making a sales pitch, they're actually looking at who they're
working with trying to figure out how to
get what they need.
Many people that I work with say they
will go to a friend's house for a party
and before they even reach for the
doorknob they get a sense of what's
going on. We use it all the time. It's
just that we haven't been brought up to
believe how important it is or
understand how important it is. So, we are
actually communicating with our animals
all the time. One of the biggest complaints that
the animals have is, “Will you
tell her to stop repeating herself?”
Because the human says, “Did you, did you…
don’t…“
And, the animal is hearing the same thing
over again: “Don't do that, don't leave
that.” We are
picturing what we want them not to do,
which is counterintuitive.
We need to picture what we want them to
do. In other words, when we form a
mental image they're picking up on it.
That’s right. So, when I
have people that are going on vacation,
I'll give them exercises to do so they
can communicate with their animals.
One of the things I warn them about is
make sure when you picture your animal,
you’re picturing your animal in your home
and you coming home to that animal. Don't
picture them out by the seaside where
you are because at that point the animal
may say, “Oh my gosh. I got to go find her.”
And, we don't want that to happen. Yeah. So, there can be a lot of
misunderstandings, even in the middle of
telepathic communication. That's right. That's why it takes practice and being
really conscious and really devoted and
wanting to have it happen.
Another
idea that I've gleaned from looking
through some of your material is the
notion that there are different
languages, that different species
of animals use. That's true.
There are different cultures for every
animal there is.
It's fascinating, because
conceptually,
what a cat may want to
communicate would not matter to a dog.
Cats feel, essentially, that dogs are
pretty slow, actually,
that they're not, as we would say, not the
sharpest knife in the drawer.
But at the same time, if you're going to
be listening to a cat you also need to
understand: cats are, from my
perspective, some of the best hunters, if
not the best hunters
on the planet.
How do they hunt? They freeze.
They watch to see what moves.
Very different from us as humans, where
we’re grabbing, reaching,
maybe not taking that time. So,
we have so much to learn from the
animals and each culture presents what
is important to it. That's what it makes
its focus on. Now, when you say culture,
are you referring to animal species? I am.
For instance, canid culture.
Canid culture is very different from ours. One
of the things that we do that drives
dogs crazy
is that when we come to meet our friends
we stand in a doorway.
Now, in the doorway - to an animal that's
coming or going from a den -
and dogs know, innately, in many species,
you can be killed leaving the den or
entering the den. The last thing you want
to do is pause in that entryway.
Not only do we pause on that entryway, we
hug each other and hold each other in
that doorway.
So animals that are... especially dogs that
are sensitive to that can be very crazy
when people come to visit. They can actually become aggressive because
they're trying to move us out of that
danger zone.
So, let's suppose that I’m a typical
human, which I guess I am, and
I'm interested in
becoming more open to what animals
are trying to communicate
to me. How would I start? The first thing
would be sitting quietly -
an understanding that you have to get
out of your own way. You have to be quiet
enough and not, “I need you to say this. I
need you to communicate in English.”
Not put what we... what our form and
definition of communication is. To sit
quietly and watch.
Sometimes it can be a flick of the tail,
because cats will come and they'll come
across and check us. We need to
understand that's language.
Being quiet and being receptive and then
closing your eyes, clearing your mind
screen,
and just being in receptivity.
For people who don't meditate it helps
to start meditating. For people who
already meditate they usually tell me
that they'll see their animal at some
point during their meditation, and that's a great beginning.
Now, when you say “their” animal - I
know we have a sense that humans own
everything around us.
I know you referred to Rumi as your
teammate, not your animal. He
isn’t mine. No, he isn’t. And I think it's
really important. There are families that
are very clear that their animals are
equal family members. They're very clear that they have
the respect and their needs need to be
met. There are others that think that an
animal is less than.
There are others that think that we are
the highest on the food chain,
which really works until you meet a
polar bear and then you discover that you're not highest on the food chain.
They're amazing hunters. Well, I
know I've seen some photos of you
with some pretty large animals.
Yeah.
I'm very fortunate and I'm very
careful,
because I am not in their culture.
So, what I may... I was raised on
Disney films.
I was raised on people going into the
desert and making friends with what...
and that's really not realistic. You have
to be respectful of that culture. You
don't just walk in and assume because
you're a human and you could do this,
that it works. No, you have to know who you're speaking
with and listening to. So,
a lot of this communication is at the intuitive
level. Let me share something with you. I
have been, over the years, engaged as you might imagine with many different
psychic groups. On one occasion
we were doing something akin to
remote viewing and it involved animal
communication with a dolphin.
This was with dolphins. The group of
people were actually this group at
the time, they were in Mexico, off the
coast of Cabo San Lucas. They told me
that in their experience the
Mexican dolphins would speak to them in
Spanish. So,
what a wonderful question and here's why.
If we look at the fact that
everything is energy,
any form of communication is energy,
it isn't effective
as communication if we limit that it
can only come in one way.
So, in my classes we work with breeze, we
work with temperature, we work with
lighting, we work with weather, we work
with what is your body sensing when
you're near this animal.
In that time - and dolphins are incredible
at reading us like that -
in that time those animals and where
we come together is the intersection of
what we have to learn. So,
if we are asking for guidance from that
animal there's really divine
interpretations that happen.
So, if you will, there's an
interpreter between us and them.
All it is is an energetic pattern
that fits our pattern. And when that
comes together that's what we hear or
experience. Now, another way of expressing, I think, what you just said is that our
subconscious is acting as something of a
filter. Absolutely. Beautiful. If
we choose to
have the subconscious raised to a higher
level then we get even higher sources of
information, not limited only to a
particular species.
Now, that gets very interesting because,
naturally, many of my viewers are
interested in higher consciousness. I
gather, perhaps like children, animals are…
it's more of a natural state for them to
be kind of in tune with the universe. Oh,
completely. We were
more in tune
in an earlier phase of who we are simply
because to exist we had to be
using telepathy, we had to be using
any of our senses that we now have shut
down. We've become so informational now,
Jeffrey, that instead of
inviting and growing our intuitive side
we have become
so left brained with all information
incoming, incoming,
which is why one of the exercises that I
give to people is to turn the sound down
on their television and see what's
really going on in a news cast, what's really going on in an interview that
we're watching, what's really being said.
Because there's a whole stream of information and many forks from that
stream. Well, communication
specialists I think, for the most part
today, would say 85 percent is non verbal.
That's... thank you… yeah.
It's not just physical, it's not just
looking at body language. You can
have people sitting very still, that are
very in tune, that know exactly what's
going on.
I mean, the most exact obvious example I
can think of that is putting ER
doctors in the same room,
soldiers returning from active duty,
you can have them sitting in silence and
they know if the guy sitting across
from them has been in the same experience they have or not. Nobody has
to say a word. Why? Because there's an
energetic patterning
that's already met, non verbally.
And that’s really the area in which you
work in, the energetics of it all.
I understand you
visualize a lot of that.
You're looking at the aura or
energy patterns around. I do that as well,
and the more
dedicated and deeper my work
gets, the more
different ways of communication are
offered to me. One time I was sitting in
a meeting with my mother - that was a
financial meeting for her - and someone
wanted her to sign a contract and pushed
it across the table.
I looked at it and off the paper rose
red lines, like we think of highlighting,
under certain sentences. Just a strip of
red. I'd never seen it before but I knew
innately this means this is out of
integrity. So, we passed it back to the woman, of
course, she was very upset.
I just said we need to think about
it, you know, as soon as we get out to the car my mom said, “What did you
see?” you know.
I didn't need to know the
legalese, I didn't need to understand that,
all I knew was it was out of integrity.
It's also about you trusting
yourself when you get these images. Yeah,
it's what I call the “T” muscle, the trust
muscle, you have to exercise it. You
have to take chances.
People used to refer to that what we
have is a gift.
I loved… I read somewhere many years
ago that the gift is the first day you are
born. After that it’s skill.
You have to be willing to take chances,
put it out there,
and you have to understand -
in some ways there's no right and wrong,
in the sense that in time you may come
to understand what the meaning of what
you were shown was. It may not happen
right away. That takes years
and trust.
You may say, “But, this seems so real.” It
did, but it may not have happened yet.
You might be looking into the future.
Yes. I had some really heavy
experiences when I was 12. I had a
nightmare that kept recurring.
It was so scary to me and it was so real.
My parents finally took me to a psychic,
Lotte Von Strahl, who
said to me, “You need to know that
this is a real thing that will happen.
Don't be surprised if you read about it
in the newspaper.”
And, 4 years later I was walking down
the hall in my parents’ house and the
newspaper - it was as though it levitated -
it didn't levitate.
But, I froze and I realized,
“Oh my gosh. This is it. It's in the
newspaper.” It was the Tate-LaBianca
murders. I wouldn't tell my parents about
it because I was afraid they'd be involved. {merge and delete}
But, now you're talking about
something that comes up almost
inevitably for people who open up to
these realms, and that is that there are
dangers and fears
associated with it. One of them being
the fear that other people will think
you're crazy. You know, it's interesting, my parents - who
were on the board of ASPR (American
Society for Psychic Research) for 17
years -
they told me at 3 years old, “Honey,
that's nice but just make sure you keep it inside the house.”
So, they let me know it was okay to talk
about it inside the house. But, it wasn't
until I was nine that they got involved
with ASPR.
Well, and you're fortunate. Most parents
don't have such an affiliation.
Right, that's true. I'm not sure
which came first, the chicken or the egg
on that one. But,
as people begin to sense
that they're having experiences that are
not part of the
normal human consensus
reality that becomes a little
frightening for people, that's where trust is important. That's where trust is
important. Also,
so many more people are
waking up - that's usually the expression -
for me it's remembering, I think
everybody is just starting to remember
now. There are people you can find
that have like experiences. There's a
lot of comfort in that, there's a lot of
comfort in that. It's so important to
support each other. This is a time when
we need more communication,
consciously, that we're taking in.
One of the points you made earlier when
we were speaking is that as humans
become more open to communicating
and listening to animals they also open
themselves up to
a wide range of their own capabilities.
That's right. So, I have a lot of people
that come into the classes that want to
hear their animals speak,
but they leave realizing, “Oh my gosh, I
actually have been hearing more.”
Rather than being chastised for it they
get excited about it. They're given
permission, they give themselves a hall
pass to make it okay,
to make it okay,
to be in receivership for other forms
of information. Then of course we go
into protection and awareness because you don't want to just put an
antenna up and catch whatever is flying
by, that's not the point, not usable.
So, discernment is important. Absolutely,
discernment. Well, Maranda Alcott, this has been
an enlightening discussion. I’m growing
already. Although I haven't been
with an animal in my family for decades
you're making me rethink,
or I'm choosing to rethink that.
Thank you so much for being with me.
Thank you for inviting us. it's been a
pleasure to have you and Rumi here
in the studio. Thank you, Jeffrey.
And, thank you
for being with us.
[Music]
